contentrichtext.text: {{refimprove|date=February 2012}} {{Infobox political party |country = Iraq |party_name = Iraqi Turkmen Front |native_name = Irak Türkmen Cephesi<br>الجبهة التركمانية العراقي<br>Al-Jabhat Al-Turkmaniyah Al-Iraqi |colorcode = #00CCFF |party_logo = [[File:Flag of Iraq Turkmen Front.svg|200px]] |leader = [[Sadettin Ergeç]] |ideology = [[Iraqi Turkmens|Turkmen]] interests |foundation = 1995 in [[Erbil]], [[Iraq]] |colours = [[Blue]] |headquarters = |website = [http://www.kerkuk.net/ http://www.kerkuk.net/] |seats1_title = Seats in the [[Council of Representatives of Iraq]]: |seats1 = {{Infobox political party/seats|5|325|hex=#0000FF}} }} The '''Iraqi Turkmen Front''' ({{lang-tr|Irak Türkmen Cephesi}}, {{lang-ar|الجبهة التركمانية العراقي}} ''Al-Jabhat Al-Turkmaniyah Al-Iraqi'') is a political movement founded in 1995 which seeks to represent the [[Iraqi Turkmen|Turkmen people]] of [[Iraq]]. Since the fall of [[Saddam Hussein]] in 2003, the ITF has contested control of [[Kirkuk]] and other areas of northern Iraq.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ifpo.revues.org/1115|title=The Iraqi Turkmen Front|author=Raber Tal’at Jawhar|accessdate=February 26, 2012}}</ref> The ITF claims a region named Turkmeneli (literally meaning the "land of the Turkmens"<ref name="Anderson & Stansfield 2009 loc=57">{{Harvnb|Anderson|Stansfield|2009|loc=57}}.</ref>) as the homeland by the Iraqi Turkmens. Turkmeneli includes within its boundaries [[Kirkuk]], [[Tel Afar]], [[Erbil]], [[Mandali, Iraq|Mandali]], [[Mosul]], and [[Tuz Khormato]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Anderson|Stansfield|2009|loc=16}}.</ref><ref name="Anderson & Stansfield 2009 loc=57"/> ==ITF Composition== The ITF is a coalition of the following political parties: *Iraqi National Turkmen Party (INTP), founded in 1988 and operated in the northern [[Iraqi no-fly zones]] *Turkmeneli Party, founded in 1992 in [[Northern Cyprus]] as the ''Turkmen Union Party'' *Provincial Turkmen Party *Movement of the Independent Turkmen *Iraqi Turkmen Rights Party *Turkmen Islamic Movement of Iraq ==Election results== In the [[Iraqi legislative election, December 2005]], the ITF list (#630) polled 76,434 votes, or 0.7% nationwide, according to the uncertified published results. The overwhelming majority of those votes were cast in [[At-Ta'mim Governorate|Kirkuk Province]], where the ITF won more than 10% of the total. Most of the rest of the ITF's votes were in [[Salah ad Din Governorate|Salah ad Din]] province. According to the full official results of that election, the ITF is entitled to only one seat in the permanent [[National Assembly of Iraq|National Assembly]]. The party has been funded deeply by the Turkish administration and military.<ref>{{Raber Tal’at Jawhar. "The Iraqi Turkmen Front". Retrieved February 26, 2012.}}</ref> In the aftermath of the first [[Iraqi legislative election, January 2005|Iraqi parliamentary election in 2005]], the ITF lodged a number of formal complaints to the [[Independent High Electoral Commission|Independent Electoral Commission of Iraq]] alleging vote fraud on the part of the [[Democratic Patriotic Alliance of Kurdistan|Kurdish parties]] and protesting the Commission's decision to allow Kurdish [[internally displaced person]]s and [[refugee]]s to vote in the places from which they had been expelled under Saddam Hussein. In the election, they received just over 90,000 votes, or 1.1% of votes cast, earning them three seats in the trasitional National Assembly of Iraq. In the 2009 Iraqi Kurdistan legislative election, the ITF polled just 7,077 votes, or 0.38% of the popular vote, winning 1 seat. In the 2010 Iraqi national elections, the ITF candidate in the Turkmen stronghold of [[Kirkuk]], [[Arshad al-Salihi]], won 59,732 votes as a part of [[Iyad Allawi]]'s [[Iraqi National Movement|Iraqiya List]]. This was second only to [[Khalid Shwani]] of the [[Patriotic Union of Kurdistan]], who won 68,522 votes. This is a very high figure, since the Turkmens historically made up roughly 10-20% of the population and as such, much of the support for the Turkmen candidate must have been gained from the Arab supporters.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Iraqi political parties}} [[Category:Turkmen political parties in Iraq]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1995]] [[Category:Political parties in Iraq]]
